item.title: ADS
item.description: NTFS uses Alternate Data Streams (ADS) to store additional data about a file. It was traditionally introduced so that it could provide compatibility for file sharing with the older Hierarchical File system (HFS) of Macintosh systems. Each file on an NTFS file system typically has one main data stream, which contains the file’s primary contents. ADS allows additional data streams to be attached to the file, each identified by a unique stream name. For example, consider a file named document.txt. In addition to the main data stream, which holds the file’s contents, an alternate stream called document.txt:hidden_data could be created. This stream can contain any data, such as text, images, or even executable code, without altering the visible file size or content in Windows Explorer.
